content: [Applause] hey guys welcome back to another episode
of black magic crafts I like many of you have spent way too many hours in this
hobby drawing little individual breaks and to be honest I kind of hate that
part of the hobby and that part of building terrain and buildings it's not
that fun to spend hours drawing little individual bricks I mean maybe it is for
you but it's not for me and I'm guessing I'm not alone in that I dislike it so
much that as you've seen before in past videos and project showcases that I
often actually cut little individual foam bricks and glue them on one by one
to buildings because I find that less annoying than drawing and carving them
all out that being said while that looks really good it is still also very time
consuming and I've always been after a better option I've been familiar with
for a while the texture rolling pins by green stuff WorldCom they are acrylic
rolling pins that are designed to imprint various patterns and textures
quickly into green stuff or clay or putty for a miniature basis and I've
often wondered how well they would work on XPS foam if it would scale up and be
a useful tool for building terrain I had thought about them for a long time but
never really gotten around to actually ordering any until recently on the
Blackmagic craft fellowship group which is the private face
a group for my patreon supporters at a certain level a discussion started about
these rollers and whether or not they work on foam and a few members actually
posted some pictures of the stuff they had done on foam with these rolling pins
it kind of sealed the deal for me that this was a viable option and possibly a
really good one for doing stonework on XPS foam I needed to know for myself
I needed to test these rolling pins out to see if it's something that I would
recommend so I reached out to green stuff world let him know who I was and
asked them if they could send me you know some of their stuff to demo and try
out and they did they sent me a couple rolling pins and a few other items but
what I really cared about was these pins they offer a wide variety of patterns I
don't know how many it actually it is but there's a lot of different patterns
some in various sizes and they sent me two that I think would be really useful
in terrain building one is a pavement kind of like an old medieval cobblestone
street and one is bricks a nice interlocking brick pattern that would be
great for walls so I excitedly tried the mode on XPS foam and I would really like
to share with you guys what I found now keep in mind again these rolling pins
are designed to use on clay or green stuff or modeling putty and without
question they're phenomenal for that 100% work great the real question is how
do they how do they handle XPS foam on a larger scale so let's go over to the
workbench and I'll show you how those tests turned out so I have here set up
two strips of XPS foam and these are three inches wide and the reason that
they are three inches wide is that that is typically the height at which I build
my buildings walls so for these rolling pins to be
effective they have to work well on three inch wide material which obviously
they will because they are quite a bit wider than that I also have these strips
set up right up against the wall so that when I attempt to roll the pin to give
these the texture they are pushed towards the wall and they don't move
around on me just for a little bit of stability and I have here two of the
pins that greenstuff world offers a brick pattern and a pavement pattern and
keep in mind they do have other ones that would be really useful like the
cobblestone ones that they didn't happen to send me but here we're gonna demo the
bricks and the pavements this is gonna be really awkward to do the way I have
this camera set up so you can see it I'm gonna have to reach around in a weird
way however we're gonna try here so first I'm gonna try this pavement one
which I'm hoping will work well because I have plans of making a bunch of roads
for towns and for months I've been dreading hand carving pavement so I'm
hoping that this works really well the trick to this that I can already see is
that you're gonna have to keep consistent pressure on this all the way
through even and also you're gonna have to try to roll this pin straight and not
like this so that the pattern stays pretty parallel to the piece that you're
gonna use and I've done a few tests already and I've learned that slow
steady pressure seems to be best so I'm pushing down with a fair amount of force
and just carefully rolling forward trying to keep the pin at a nice 90
degree angle to my foam and trying to keep pressure across the whole width of
the rolling pin and there we go
and I now have a cobblestone pattern that looks pretty damn great in a matter
of seconds it would have taken me an hour at least or more to carve this in
by hand so now let's take a look at the brick one and this brick pattern is a
very small brick pattern so they're give me a lot of detail in this and it's
going to be crucial that I keep the pressure even across the whole piece and
especially with this one keep it running you know parallel so that the brick
pattern doesn't drift again I'm in a very awkward position here with the
camera but such is life as a youtuber right here we go even pressure and it's
looking really good there I would say it's a success the
brick pattern came out really nicely there's one spot where I didn't keep the
pressure down but it actually still looks fine I did drift kind of
off-center so I'm wondering if when working with a brick pattern like this
it would be better to use an oversized piece and then cut your piece rip it on
the you know straight brick line or I'm sure with a bit of practice it's easy to
keep it straight or use some kind of guide this is just first initial tests
there's one thing I've noticed with these rolling pins and keep in mind I've
only been using them for a couple days but I've noticed that the imprint on
them seems to work far better on XPS foam on a surface where I've cut it
myself on the procs on table when I try to indent it directly onto the factory
surface I find it doesn't indent quite as well so it's definitely beneficial to
break your pieces down on a hot wire tool first because I think it makes the
pieces I don't know take the indentation a little bit better but that being said
it still works like on foam off the shelf now the really important part is
because you can't probably see this too well it's painting it I'm gonna skip
ahead I'm gonna paint this using my regular painting technique that I would
use on anything that I hand-carved I'll take a look and see how good it looks or
bad but I'm hoping good
so we've gone ahead and painted both of these test pieces out using my regular
painting method that I would have used had I hand you know drawn or carved
these patterns I wanted to make sure that the patterns really held up to that
method including the Mod Podge layer because the Mod Podge has a tendency to
you know kind of remove very very fine details and I wanted to make sure that
these indentations held up to the Mod Podge coating and then the paint and
honestly they did really well so with both of them I did my black Mod Podge
layer a dark gray a light gray dry brush than a white dry brush and then a black
wash over everything and again I was a little bit concerned that the fact that
these indentations are a little bit shallow wouldn't you know take the wash
as well but they did it turned out great I am actually a little bit surprised at
how well these have turned out for the speed at which you can make them it's
very very exciting I you know what let's let's take a few
close-up looks at these the wash is still drying a little bit and then let's
zoom out and I'm gonna give you my overall rating of these green stuff
world rollers
pretty damn good-looking test pieces from these rolling pins I gotta say I'm
really happy with the results now full disclosure just so you know exactly with
all transparency how my opinions are being formed green stuff world has not
offered any funding or anything for this review or video I simply asked them for
some stuff to demo they sent me a couple things and this is
where we're at so this is not a paid advertisement I'm really enthusiastic
about these pins because they are good and they work I got if I have to rape
them for XPS foam I'm gonna give them a solid a the they're not gonna get an A+
simply because they're not the easiest thing to roll it'd be nice if they had
some handles and the texture like it could be a little bit deeper but again
these are meant for working on modeling putty not foam but they happen to work
really well on foam and I don't think I'm gonna be drying brickwork ever again
on on walls because I could make for building walls and glue them together in
minutes something that would normally taking a couple nights of work I can do
in a minute and the results honestly side by side with the stuff I
hand-carved these are arguably better I don't think it looks as good as when you
individually glue bricks on I think that is the best way in terms of quality of
look but this week's smashes and destroys hand carving stonework and
where it's really more important I think is with this kind of a cobblestone
pattern there's no way I could even draw this accurately it's a way too complex
of a pattern to small and this is gonna be awesome for when I finally get around
to doing my city streets that I've been planning for a while but I've been a
waiting that project because I didn't want to have to carve this okay
now I can do it keep in mind this is just two of the patterns offered by them
they have many more some that I really wish they had also sent me they have a
couple of cobblestone ones like kind of like a river rock that would be
phenomenal for buildings and you know fantasy terrain I'm probably gonna have
to order those myself now because and then send me those ones but I highly
recommend you take a look through their website and catalogue at these pins they
got the black magic seal of approval I will be getting more of them for myself
without a doubt the good news for you guys is that the other part of this
equation when I reached out to them and ask them for these pins I also asked
them if they could set up some kind of promotion for you guys if you want to
purchase them there is no black magic craft affiliate
link situation going on here I won't get any kind of kickback from them I just
want you to purchase them because I think they're good and I think they
deserve the business and I asked them if there's anything they could do for my
viewers and they set up a modest discount code for you guys to use if you
are ordering anything from their website until October 22nd you can use the promo
code black magic craft 5 no spaces and that will take 5% off your total order
price I mean by all means if you're thinking about it I think these pins are
a great investment for serious terrain builders that want to tackle buildings
and streets and that sort of stuff I might even just start using them for
dungeon to house I don't know I'm pretty excited by them check them out pick the
ones you like use the promo code you got till October 22nd before it expires and
that's a kind of the only way that they'll be able to track how I'm giving
me these and and you guys hearing about them how that transferred to sales for
them so I'm hoping that if a lot of you guys do purchase them using that code
that they'll see that it was worth it to give me some stuff and I mean
more stuff that I can demo for you guys because I'm always excited to show you
guys cool things and in theory tell you which things to avoid it just happens
that so far like the stuff that I've reached out to ask for has been really
good so I haven't had to tell you about them by it I I know
these product videos aren't necessarily as greatest tutorials but they are
something that I think is important moving forward in this channel because
getting the right tools and equipment to make your bills more successful is
important as usual if you want to pick up any of the other tools and supplies
that I use and support the channel by purchasing them head over to Blackmagic
crafty a check out my Amazon affiliate store then you can purchase the tools
and supplies that I use that are available on Amazon and by purchasing
them you send a small Commission my way that helps fund these videos of course
if you really want to help out the channel head over to my patreon page
consider supporting there and if you support at the $5 a month level or
higher you get membership to the Fellowship which is the private Facebook
community of awesome cool crafters who support the channel and the crafts and
again are the reason that this like many of my videos happen because it is a
circular ring of inspiration there and I love it and I would love to see more you
guys join up there draw me your comments below let me know what you think if
there's other green stuff world product that you really want to see tested let
me know and I'll see what I can do hit that like button or hit the dislike
button honestly guys for those of you who feel the need to hit dislike on
videos for whatever vindictive reason just know as far as YouTube's algorithms
are concerned a liking to dislike are the same so for those of you who feel
the need to hit dislike on my videos thanks for the support and thanks for
driving up my traffic on YouTube anyways until next time guys Cheers
happy crafting have a great weekend and make your life a little bit easier maybe
